posts.cooked: It would be nice if Signal Foundation shares its Tax returns. They are supposedly available publicly through IRS Website, but I only found 2018 returns there.

Signal Technology Foundation Form 990 (2018) General Discussion
Signal is a great app and I want it to continue to be available long into the future. I was looking at the Signal Technology Foundation‚Äôs Form 990, and it says that the foundation has $100 million in assets, but also $105 million in liabilities, specifically in the form of a loan issues by a member of the foundation. The blog post about the Foundation‚Äôs creation said that it was being started with a $50 million dollar grant. Was that grant actually a loan? Is this loan due at any specific time, ‚Ä¶
That‚Äôs only the 2018 returns, which @aaaaa already mentioned having found. Are there ones available for the following years?

posts.name: Joe
posts.cooked:
aaaaa:

It would be nice if Signal Foundation shares its Tax returns. They are supposedly available publicly through IRS Website , but I only found 2018 returns there.

IRS has been busy sending out checks and doing the bidding of the administration. Not to mention the USPS being used as a political football

Here Notice on the IRS website " Data Update Delays

Expect delays in data updates for the Tax Exempt Organization Search tool. We are still processing paper-filed 990 series received April 2020 and later.

System Limitations Cause Some Inaccurate Revocation Dates
Organizations on the auto-revocation list with a revocation date between April 1 and July 14, 2020, should have a revocation date of July 15, 2020. See Revocation Date of Certain Organizations for details."

Plus the delay in filing deadline, however I am sure that if you reach out to the Signal foundation they will post the returns here if they do not have any pending issues with the IRS for 2019.

posts.name: kara
posts.cooked:
Having another look at the newest Form 990 I wonder how the subcategories in the ‚ÄúRevenue‚Äù listing work, especially ‚Äú8 Contributions and grants‚Äù and ‚Äú9 Program service revenue‚Äù.

‚ÄúContributions and grants‚Äù stays the same compared to last year, being the by farbiggest part of the income. In the same time, ‚ÄúProgram service revenue‚Äù increased by a factor of 50!
Are the donations to Signal foundation classified as ‚ÄúProgram service revenue‚Äù? Such a large increase in donations would be a great success! But then I stil wonder what are the other 22 million listed as ‚ÄúContributions and grants‚Äù?

Unfortunately I don‚Äôt know anything about how the U.S. tax reporting system works.

posts.name: Jessica
posts.cooked:
The Form 990 for 2024 is now available, they lost $8 million. Tried to pick out some details from the full filing:

  • $2 million increase in compensation, likely just staff raises, benefits costs, etc. Reported headcount was 52, up 1.
  • Donations fell by $800 000, to $21.8 million
  • The largest factor was the loss of $1.2 million in royalties and $4 million in Program Service Revenue (both licensing fees and service revenue)

The balance sheet shows the loss was mostly covered with cash assets, decreasing from $16 million at the start of the year to just under $11 million.

posts.cooked: ‚Ä¶that sounds worrisome? Any idea of how this will persist through 2025?

posts.name: Jessica
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôm honestly not sure. Their blog post breaking down their costs was published in November 2023, so any growth (or in this case, lack of it) would be fully reflected in the 2024 filing. The only good thing I can see is that managed to keep service provider expenses down. Costs for AWS and GCP increased by $0.8 million, which was offset by decreased Azure rates and SMS verification fees (mainly Twilio, also MessageBird).

But I don‚Äôt think that will be the case for 2025; they were already seeing significant growth (Finland, Netherlands, Germany) before Signalgate happened, which will really hit those SMS charges. And the wide rollout (plus removal of the ‚ÄúBeta‚Äù tag) for Secure Backups is also coming up.

link_counts.title: Signal >> Blog >> Privacy is Priceless, but Signal is Expensive

posts.cooked: Is it just me thinking they should be charging more for the full backup service than just covering that particular service‚Äôs costs?

posts.name: Jessica
posts.cooked:
I think they end up achieving that, based on some comments from the announcement thread:

Signal Blog: Introducing Signal Secure Backups

After the Google tax it‚Äôs ~$1.40 earned revenue per transaction. It‚Äôs a little bit more until the first $1M made.

Signal Blog: Introducing Signal Secure Backups

It‚Äôs based on Cloudflare R2: Pricing ¬∑ Cloudflare R2 docs . Would be 1.5$ for 100 GB excluding ingress frees so they either have a deal with them of assume most people won‚Äôt fill the storage.

For reference, I have almost 34 000 unique attachments over 4 years, and my backup is 16.3 GB. Six people like me could fit into a 100 GB block for $9 of post-Google revenue. Costs would be $1.50 + nightly uploads and occasional restores, paying users subsidizing the opt-in free tier.

Edit: some rough math for ingress/egress fees

For R2 storage, Class A operations cover writes ($4.50 per million ops), Class B covers reads ($0.36 per million ops). I‚Äôll ignore the cost for the initial upload.

Class A:

  • 34 000 attachments √∑ 4 years ‚âà 23 attachments a day. I‚Äôll double that to 50 (which also includes the one daily upload for all text messages).
  • Assume a super conservative free/paid ratio of 100:1, so 606 users in the 100 GB block.

50 daily uploads √ó 30 days √ó 606 users = 909 000 Class A ops √ó $4.50/million ops = $4.10 ingress

Class B:

  • Let‚Äôs say each user does 2 full downloads a month (overkill even if everyone needed to relink a desktop monthly):

2 monthly downloads √ó 606 users = 1212 Class B ops √ó $0.36/million ops = $0.004 egress

Result:

$8.40 - $1.50 - $4.10 - $0.004 = $2.79 net income

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: I think the challenge is affordability. In some places $2 is multiple days of pay.

Not to turn it into a different conversation, but yes, I‚Äôve been to some of those places. Many people still have what would be very expensive (for them) phones there (they would have to have a phone to need a Signal backup in the first place). If $2 is a lot, they can make do with the free backup - we all cut corners to not go into debt and survive wherever we live.

End of the day, Signal is based in the US and has to survive in the US.
If it‚Äôs a case of we ‚Äòwesterners‚Äô subsidise the service for the people who can‚Äôt afford it, I‚Äôm all for that too.
